patterns: What do you know about northern lights?
responses: The northern lights are an atmospheric phenomenon that's regarded as the Holy Grail of skywatching.

The northern lights, or the aurora borealis, are the beautiful dancing waves of light that have captivated people for millennia. But for all its beauty, this spectacular light show is a rather violent event.

patterns: WHERE AND WHEN TO SEE THE NORTHERN LIGHTS
Where can i see northeren lights?
Where can i spot northeren lights
Where can i sport aurora effects?
responses: The northern lights are happening 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year, said photographer Chad Blakely, owner of northern lights tour company Lights Over Lapland. you need to be at the right place at the right time.

The best place to see the northern lights is any destination in the -auroral zone the area within an approximately 1,550-mile (2,500 kilometers) radius of the North Pole. it's best to base yourself in a destination with solid infrastructure, like Fairbanks, Alaska; Yellowknife, Canada; Svalbard, Norway; Abisko National Park, in Sweden; Rovaniemi, Finland; and pretty much anywhere in Iceland.

patterns: WHERE AND WHEN TO SEE THE NORTHERN LIGHTS
When can i watch Northern lights?
what time is the best to watch aurora?
responses: The best time of year to see the northern lights is between September and April, when the sky gets dark enough to see the aurora. (Northern locales experience the midnight sun, or 24 hours of daylight in the summer.) The most action usually happens between 9 p.m. and 3 a.m., according to the Geophysical Institute of the University of Alaska Fairbanks. Keep the moon phases in mind, as a bright full moon might fill the night sky with light. Check local weather forecasts as well, because you won't be able to spot the aurora through the clouds.
You can monitor aurora forecasts from the University of Alaska Fairbanks' Geophysical Institute and NOAA, which offers both three-day and 30-minute forecasts.

A colorful sky with colors red, green, blue, yellow and pink
Red: At its highest altitudes, Green: At lower altitudes, Blue: At yet lower altitudes, Yellow and pink are a mix of red and green or blue. Auroras changes with time.

patterns: What are the past occurenecs examples of northern lights?
responses: The auroras that resulted from the great geomagnetic storm on both 28 August and 2 September 1859

The discovery of a 1770 Japanese diary in 2017 depicting auroras above the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto suggested that the storm may have been 7% larger than the Carrington event, which affected telegraph networks.
The Northern Lights are actually the result of collisions between gaseous particles in the Earth's atmosphere with charged particles released from the sun's atmosphere.

Variations in colour are due to the type of gas particles that are colliding. The most common auroral color, a pale yellowish-green, is produced by oxygen molecules located about 60 miles above the earth. Rare, all-red auroras are produced by high-altitude oxygen, at heights of up to 200 miles. Nitrogen produces blue or purplish-red aurora.

responses: The best places in the world are usually closer to the Arctic Circle, including Alaska, Canada, Iceland, Greenland, Norway, Sweden and Finland
One can spot the southern lights in the southern hemisphere. Still, the northern lights are the star of the show.

patterns: What are fun facts about aurora?
What are interesting facts about northern lights?
responses: the term aurora borealis–northern dawn–is jointly credited to have first been used by Pierre Gassendi (1592-1655) and Galileo Galilei (1564-1642), who both witnessed a light display on Sept. 12, 1621.
The height of the displays can occur up to 1000 km (620 miles), although most are between 80-120 km.
Auroras tend to be more frequent and spectacular during high solar sunspot activity, which cycles over approximately eleven years.
Yellowknife (Northwest Territories, Canada) is the capital for aurora tourism.
